description: Borrowed from French bisque, possibly from Biscaye.

entries.meaning: Of a pale pinkish brown colour.
A thick creamy soup made from fish, shellfish, meat or vegetables.
(ceramics) A form of unglazed earthenware; biscuit.

verbs.description: bisque (third-person singular simple present bisques, present participle bisquing, simple past and past participle bisqued)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To prepare ceramics in the bisque style.
examples: I use an electric kiln strictly for bisquing my pots.

description: Borrowed from French bisque, of unknown origin; Émile Littré, Dictionnaire de la langue française, suggests a comparison with Spanish bisca (“gambling house, gambling den”).

definitionGroups.group: (sports) An extra turn, free point or some other advantage allowed.

entries.meaning: A free turn in a handicap croquet match.
A free point in a handicap real tennis match.

definitionGroups.group: (chiefly British) Exemption from work or other duty on a particular day.

entries.meaning: (chiefly BBC, historical) A day's leave an employee may take without warning or reason and not be counted as annual leave.
(British parliament) Permission for an MP to be absent from a vote, granted by the whips when the absence is not likely to affect the outcome.
